awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Translational Research in Psychological Sciences: Human Factors at Texas Tech University
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is funded from the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Sites program in the SBE Directorate. As such, it has both scientific and societal benefits, and it integrates research and education. The REU Site at Texas Tech University advances research that aims to understand the cognitive, social, and physical capabilities and limitations of people and translates that knowledge to practical benefits for society. This area of psychological sciences, known as human factors, which is a subfield of applied experimental psychology, is vital in addressing societal challenges including those in aviation, health care, energy, transportation, and cyber-security, creating a large and increasing workforce need for human factors professionals. The REU Site will introduce undergraduates to an area with plentiful job opportunities and develop their research skills, making them attractive to graduate programs in various disciplines, and to industry employers seeking individuals who can apply research training to practical issues such as evaluating products and user interfaces. The REU Site supports diversity in social and behavioral sciences by recruiting under-represented groups to participate. Results of the research will advance the state of the art in the field and will have broad practical implications including traffic crashes, patient safety, education, human-robot interaction, substance use and misuse, health-based disparities, baggage screening, and occupational injuries. 

The main goals of the REU Site are to engage undergraduates in behavioral research that has clear value in solving real-world problems, to develop research, teamwork, and communication skills applicable to any career in social and behavioral sciences, and to increase the number of undergraduates-- particularly those in underrepresented groups, who pursue graduate education and careers in human factors psychology. During each of three years, 8 undergraduates will work closely with faculty members at Texas Tech University on behavioral research with important applications such as driving, human-robot interaction; surgery; enhancement of student learning; applications of neuroscience to baggage screening; substance use and misuse; health-based disparities; and occupational injuries.

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

Behavioral science has been recognized as critically important in addressing societal challenges in a wide range of domains such as aviation, health care, and transportation. Behavioral science research contributed to the development of the third brake light (in rear windshield) which significantly reduced rear-end collisions. Analyses of teams led to crew resource management training, which enhances communications in teams and reduces human error in the cockpit, and to the development of tools that improve teamwork and create a safety culture in health care. There is a large and increasing workforce need for professionals who can apply behavioral sciences to real-world problems. The current project was designed to help address this need by engaging 23 undergraduate students in behavioral research that has implications for real-world problems, and developing their research, teamwork, and communication skills. During the eight-week summer  program, each student worked under the supervision of a faculty mentor on a rigorous research project that had clear practical relevance and advanced knowledge in the field. Topics varied widely and included perceptual issues in driving, human factors in the design of election ballots, effects of restorative environments for sustained attention and implications for the workplace, sleep quality and inflammation in spousally bereaved individuals, and identity management strategies in leadership interviews. Students participated in professional development lectures on topics such as developing a resume and interviewing for a job, and they gave a presentation on their research.


In a study to assess the effectiveness of the training program, students completed surveys, interviews, and journal entries. They reported that the program provided them with skills and knowledge to prepare graduate school applications, conduct research, and enter the professional world. Nearly all of the students presented a lecture on their research at a conference or published it in a journal. Students learned the practical value of behavioral sciences. After the program, 18 students completed or enrolled in graduate or professional schools (8 doctoral, 8 master's 1 law, 1 dental), and one secured an industry job in Human Factors.


The research conducted during the program advanced the state-of-the-art in the field. For example, one study was designed to address the source of sentence comprehension deficits for individuals with language deficits following stroke, specifically examining the role of working memory abilities.  The results showed that those who had difficulty maintaining word meaning information in working memory had greater difficulty in understanding sentences with complex grammatical structures whereas those who had difficulty maintaining speech sound information had less of a comprehension impairment. The findings have implications for rehabilitation of working memory to improve comprehension, indicating that focusing on training the maintenance of word meanings is likely to be of benefit.

In a field survey study, data showed that a job applicant's race and gender intersect to shape interviewer perceptions and ratings.  Perceived characteristics, such as competence and warmth, were shaped not only by qualifications (e.g., job experience) but also by visible identity group membership--whether individuals belong to marginalized race and gender groups or not. Results have practical implications for organizations to help increase equity in interview procedures and counter current disparity.

In a study of a novel face-name associative memory task using naturalistic stimuli, older adults struggled to remember faces and face-name pairs more than young adults. However, while young adults remembered emotional faces better than neutral faces, older adults selectively remembered positive faces. Although difficulty remembering faces and names is a common struggle for many people and gets more difficult with age, this novel task may provide a sensitive measure of age-related changes in memory that can be a useful tool towards the early detection of memory changes in conditions such as Alzheimer's disease. 

In a final example, a driving simulator was used to understand how drivers avoid collisions with a vehicle that is stopped on the highway in the distance. Results suggested that when the lead vehicle is moving relatively fast, drivers' responses gradually transition in phases as they assess the situation and as evidence from visual information accumulates over time. Results have practical implications for accident analyses and the design of driving automation systems.
